body.p: The Windows dir command is used to display a list of files and subdirectories in a directory. It is a built-in command in the Windows operating system.

section.title: Syntax
section.p: The syntax of the dir command is as follows:

ul.li: [drive:][path][filename] specifies the location and name of the file or directory to list. If no location is specified, the current directory is used.
/A[[:]attributes] displays files with the specified attributes. The attributes can be any combination of the following:
/B uses bare format (no heading information or summary).
/C displays the thousand separator in file sizes. This is the default.
/D displays the date in the short format specified in the Regional Settings of your computer.
/L displays the names of the files in lowercase.
/N displays long file names in a directory listing as they are entered.
/O[[:]sortorder] sorts the files in the directory. The sortorder can be any combination of the following:
D - By date and time (oldest to newest)
G - Group directories first, then files
-D - By date and time (newest to oldest)
/P pauses after each screenful of information.
/Q displays the owner of the file.
/R displays alternate data streams of the file.
/S displays files in specified directory and all subdirectories.
/T[[:]timefield] displays the time in the format specified in the Regional Settings of your computer. The timefield can be any combination of the following:
/X displays the short names generated for non-8dot3 file names.
